Then I added to the opening of the wound through that sharp medicine, until the tip of the arrow appeared visibly to us; and it took me around four months' time with him.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound was enlarged, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move them, and it did not obstruct the exit: then I did not cease to be clever and ingenious over it with various ingenious methods, until I took hold of it on a certain day with carefully made forceps, according to the form they would take at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And physicians certainly judge that a nose cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it therefore, and the wound was consolidated, and the injured part was healed with complete integrity: nor did anything harm him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of extracting a certain arrow: so that you may put that rule and significance over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not understood with narration: nor does this book comprehend it, and the prudent artisan compares a little with much: and with what is present, over what is absent: and he finds a new operation, and a new instrument, according to the descent into extraneous things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not come out from the limbs in which they are fixed, unless according to two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place into which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or through the opposite part of another.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding into the fleshy place: and it is attracted, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	What if it does not obstruct the exit at the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary that you leave it for some days, until the flesh that is around it putrefies: and its attraction is alleviated, and its egress.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in a bone, and does not obstruct the exit for you, then leave it also for some days: and try it with attraction and motion every day, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you at the outlet after a few days, then it is necessary to make perforations around the arrowhead in the bone itself from every side with a subtle drill, until the arrowheads are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the skull bone, and has already progressed into one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those bad accidents which I mentioned appear: then abstain from attracting the arrow, and leave it, until it adjusts itself after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the sifac, then death will not be prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, but only in the body of the bone, and has not penetrated to the sifac: and he remains weak for several days, and none of those accidents happen to him: then use your ingenuity in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is deeply fixed and does not obey you at attraction: then administer the drill around the arrowhead, as I narrated to you: afterwards cure the place, until he is healed.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow has already been concealed in the body and is hidden and concealed from sensation: then probe for it with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then attract it with certain instruments that are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot get above it, because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in the depth: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein: then enlarge above it, until the wound is enlarged, and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	What if there are jagged edges which hold it fast, then free the fixed flesh from them on every side, with all the ingenuity you can, and use your skills, if it cannot be raised above the fracture of the auricles, and their contortion, until it is freed.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you, when you perform the extraction of an arrowhead, in whatever location it is, then use the contortion of your hand, with forceps, towards all parts, until you make it come out: and with utmost subtlety, so that the arrowhead does not break, and its extraction becomes difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	What if you cannot get it out at that time, then leave it for some days, until the things that are around it putrefy.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then try again: for if a flow of blood is caused by the contrariety to you, then administer what we have said about curation in its chapter: and preserve your virtue from incision of a vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer your ingenuity in every way possible to extract the arrowhead: and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I have narrated to you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary, that when you pull out the arrowhead, it should be weakened according to its shape, according to what it was like at the time of the accident with the arrow.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If however it is not possible for you to do that, then administer what is possible for you according to the circumstances.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrowhead that emerges from the opposite part of the other side, or already proceeds to exteriorize something from it: or it makes a prominence on the extremity of the arrow through sensation from the upper part of the adjacent skin, and you see it standing out: therefore cut above it, and let the section be according to the quantity that the forceps can grasp in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it out: for it itself will be easy to remove.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the arrowhead impresses itself into the bone, and becomes more firmly fixed: then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave her for a few days; then return to her, until she begins to recover.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	What if the arrow's wood is in it, then push it out with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the wood has fallen out, and you want to administer a push: then insert into her a concave instrument, so that it enters into the hollow of the arrow's tail; then push it out with that itself.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push it out with an instrument entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is extracted through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	What if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary, to excavate the entire concave flesh, where the poison is; if that is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat her with what is suitable for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	What if the arrow is lodged in the breast, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the side; and it is near what you touch with a probe, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and be careful about the incision of the vein, or nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the wound, if you see fit, and treat it, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the method of forceps, with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	There are extremities similar to a bird's beak, which were made like scissors: when they grasp above the arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are made from them in many species, large, small, and medium, according to the quantity of the arrow's magnitude, and its smallness, and the width of the wound, and its constrictedness.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of a concave pusher.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of a straight pusher.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the form of a straight extremity like a rod, so that its entrance is extracted into the concave arrow, and it is pushed out with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This extremity of the pushing concavity is a concavity like a bird's wing, so that the entrance of the arrowhead may be directed into it and its impulse.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the bloodletting of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Head 47.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	Veins to be bloodletted, whose customary course is in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Out of these, there are sixteen in the head: two pulsatile veins, which are behind the ears, called two Herbae; and two arteries, which are visible on both temples; and two veins that are in both tear ducts of the eyes, which are called Aspicientes; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Jugular veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins that are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins that are bloodletted in the arms are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it comes from the lateral Sylvian region; and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Dark-colored one.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilic vein and a branch of the Cephalic vein; and the common people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic vein, and it is situated on the domestic side; and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Funis of the arm, and it is situated above the flexion; and it is the one that is bloodletted, and it is the one that appears above the thumb with a clear manifestation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Saluatella: and it is a vein which is between the ring-shaped and the smallest: and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the knee and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curve of the thumb, from the outer side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its place is at the heel, on the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein Ness: and its place is at the heel, on the outer side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other knee there are three similar veins.
Â¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	On the phlebotomy of two veins behind the Ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The phlebotomy of two veins which are behind the Ears is useful for old catarrhs, and hemicrania, and saharfat, and evil old head sores.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of one performing phlebotomy is according to what I relate.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, that the head of the weak person should be shaved: and the back of their head should be rubbed at the place of the two veins with a rough cloth, using good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the weak person should bind their neck with a thread, until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And the places of them are behind the Ears in two depressed areas of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore feel for them with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, mark it there with a branding iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the lancet, which is called the Incider.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein in the skin, until the lancet reaches the mouth of the vein.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the vein and skin to above, and make an incision into the vein with a cutting incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the measure of two joined fingers, or around that: and make the blood flow out as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then sew it up with cotton threads and leave it so until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now the initial incision of the book has preceded, and their cauterization.
Â¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Concerning the bleeding of two arteries in the temporal regions.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The bleeding of two arteries which are in the two temporal regions is a remedy for old hemicrania and also for wicked headaches and persistent eye troubles, and for an excessive flow of sharp and bitter humors to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of the bleeding is according to what I will tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The weak neck is tightened strongly until two manifest veins appear to the sense of sight, and their pulse is demonstrated under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then indeed the signs are with a branding iron.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then elevate the skin from above the vein upwards with your index finger, and insert the bleeding instrument incident below, and elevate the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you did in the two other veins: and make the blood flow according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then release the constriction of the weak one, and put your finger on the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterwards put a bandage over it and cotton threads, and tighten it above with a strong constriction: and leave it so until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now the reminder of them has preceded, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Concerning the bleeding of the vein of the forehead after the bleeding of the cephalic vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The remedy of the bleeding of the vein of the forehead is after the bleeding of the cephalic vein, for old facial weaknesses: and for hemicrania, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of its bleeding is, according to what I will tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The weakened neck with its vein, until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument that is called a Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Its shape is this.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the sharp point that is on the head of the Fossorium over the vein, and strike it with a plectrum or with another instrument in its own way; and let the blood flow according to the quantity you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the perforation of the weakened part, and bind it up, until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with a broad scalpel.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not suitable that the scalpel should be of acute extremity, like other scalpels, but rather of broad extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the scalpel is according to the transverse cut, because the bone is near; and perhaps the scalpel will be shattered when it is subtle.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of the venous scalpel operation on two tear-ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The treatment of the two veins which are in the two tear-ducts of the two eyes, is for the eye affected by itch and redness; and also for the dirtiness in the eye, and the facial disorders.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the scalpel operation on them is, that it tightens the weakened neck with its vein.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then make the incision: and you stand above its head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the scalpel operation be according to the transverse cut, along a short length, with a small scalpel, broad and somewhat flat, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the scalpel is of subtle extremity, perhaps it will be shattered.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood flow as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put a bandage over them, and bind them at night for one day, and loosen them.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the venous scalpel operation on the Nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are conducive to acute fever, and a violent headache, and facial weaknesses, such as half-paralysis, and redness that occurs on the face; especially when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of its bloodletting is, that it draws out a weak neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold the nose with your left hand, and take a subtle, long bloodletting instrument: and place it in the middle of the nostril itself, between what distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you apply your hand with the bloodletting instrument for a little while: and make the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it up at night for one hour.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly indeed.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On the bloodletting of the veins of the guides.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Indeed, the benefit of the bloodletting of the guides is for constriction of the breath, and interception of leprosy, and melancholic weaknesses, and bad eruptions and ulcers, and corroding, that is, herpes of the skin.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of their bloodletting is that it draws out a weak vein under both sides of the neck with a ligature: and let the craftsman stand over the head of the weak person, and let the weak person sit on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then apply the bloodletting instrument to the length of the bloodletting vein for a little while more broadly.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract from the blood a moderate quantity, or according to what you see as necessary for that purpose.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do similarly concerning the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards, release the ligature, and tighten the two veins with a moderate binding: so that the weak person is not suffocated.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And leave it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound will heal.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On the phlebotomy of veins by Algeber.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The phlebotomy of veins by Algeber is a remedy: because it counteracts the bitter taste in the mouth, and gum corruption, and bad ulcers, and lip fissures, and bad ulcers, even those that are in the nose and its surroundings.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that you should make the weak sit in front of you: and tie their neck with a band.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn back the lip, and look at the two veins: one of which is on the right side of the lip, and the second on its left: and the demonstration of both is through the dark bluish color.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: because around them are small, black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Make the incision therefore on both sides with an oblique incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If however you are in doubt about them, and do not know which one is: then turn to the incision of the larger one, and make it more manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do similarly with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and certainly the customary practice is to cut them: and cut the two veins that are in the lower lip.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On the phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue, after the cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The phlebotomy of the two veins that are under the tongue is a remedy: because the cephalic phlebotomy is for the affections that are in the throat, and the weakness of the uvula, and the weaknesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomizing them is that you should make the weak person sit between your hands in front of you: and raise their tongue, and look under the tongue on one side for one vein, and on the other side for another vein: and the color of both declines towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Make an incision on both sides; and take care not to injure your own hand while performing the operation.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	There are arteries underneath, and perhaps a flow of blood may occur from those arteries.
Â¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Concerning the three veins at the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	There are three veins which are operated on in the elbow, and it is in these that the customary phlebotomy is performed on all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And the phlebotomy of those is done according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pricking with a broad, blunt phlebotomy instrument; or by oiling to achieve subtlety of inclination; or by cutting with a knife-shaped phlebotomy instrument, and it is Al-nesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Al-nesil is, which is suitable for the incision.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them there are broad and subtle species according to the amplitude of the veins and their constriction. The form of the phlebotomy instrument is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening concave, full, protruding, visible, thick veins, and those that contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomy instrument is of lesser width, and more subtle at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for phlebotomy of subtle veins, which contain thin, clear blood.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Concerning the phlebotomy of the Basilica vein.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The Basilica, however, which is one of those three veins of phlebotomy, is a help.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the diseased places which are beneath the throat and neck, from that which follows the chest and stomach; and it is suitable for the phlebotomist to perform phlebotomy with caution, lest there be fear of bleeding from the artery that lies beneath.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he has erred and added to the puncture of phlebotomy, he will cut into that artery and cause a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary not to perform phlebotomy with a pointed phlebotome; instead it should be cutting with Al-nesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	What if the basilic vein does not appear with a clear and manifest appearance, then it is necessary to transfer to another one, and to change to a different branch of it: or to use a phlebotome in place of the funis of the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is clear and should be cut with a phlebotome Al-nesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you want to perform phlebotomy on the same one, then it is necessary to constrict the arm beforehand, so that you touch the place until you recognize the site of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place with a branding iron, afterwards constrict the arm, and cut the vein at an oblique section with a phlebotome Al-nesil, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware lest the percussion falls through the space to the location of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you observe, as you constrict the ligament, an inflammation at the place which you marked with a branding iron, then that inflation is an arterial inflation: therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	What if you see the blood at the phlebotomy jumping out, like the urine of a child, and it is thin, red blood: then know that it is from an arterial blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then press down, and put your finger on the space for a long time, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore the blood is stopped (for it is often stopped), then constrict the arm, and release it: and beware lest the weak one be moved by its motion: and let him be above his fear of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move him for some days, until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If however the bleeding does not stop, and it overcomes you: and there is no present remedy for you at that moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For the extremities are constricted, and the bleeding stops.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a fistula dressing, and bind it: take one half, and tie it above the place of the vein's constriction with a ligature and soft padding until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the bleeding stops, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then treat it with the treatment that preceded, remembering the place from which the powder of the bleeding stopped the flow of blood: and the stopping of its blood is not difficult in many circumstances, because of the small location of the wound, and the possibility of ligature from the arm.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On the Phlebotomy of the Dark Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The phlebotomy of the Dark Vein is beneficial, because it draws blood from the superior part of the head and the inferior part of the body: therefore, since it is composed of the basilic branch and the cephalic branch, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it suits the phlebotomist to be above fear from his phlebotomy, for beneath it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, and finds a nerve, it happens that numbness occurs in it, and the healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it may not be fully healed.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If however it is hidden in certain men, and is subtle, and does not show itself: then it is necessary that you place your phlebotomy where the phlebotomist makes an incision with Alnesil, and divides the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	Since if the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in its length.
Â¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the Veins of the Head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The treatment of the Veins of the Head is phlebotomy, because it draws blood from the head and relieves the diseases of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary to perform phlebotomy properly on this vein, if you wish, by pricking with an olive-shaped phlebotome or a myrtle-shaped one: because it is the healthiest of all the veins, since there is no artery underneath, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, it is convenient for you to take care during phlebotomy, so that you should touch the head with the phlebotome only lightly, and seek a more tender spot: and it will not harm if you do not find it with the first strike, so that you may repeat it several times over the same spot.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, perhaps there may be a relapse in certain individuals when they are not phlebotomized on the first strike, but that relapse does not harm them in any way.
Â¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of Phlebotomy and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of Phlebotomy, however, and its accidents arising from it, are things which you should consider in its proper performance.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, therefore, it is necessary that you know this: that phlebotomy should not be administered unless for the conservation of health, and its preservation, and caution against the onset of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that phlebotomy should be performed on one of the three veins which are in the elbow, namely the Cephalic, and the Fusca, and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that phlebotomy should be performed at the beginning of Spring, on an empty stomach, and in the spring season, and autumn, and winter after digestion, when signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let phlebotomy be performed on the first day, or on the third, after three hours have passed from the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Bloodletting that is administered to the sick does not have a predetermined hour; but when it provokes convenience and necessity at that time, whether at night, or during the day, and at every hour, and at every moment.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not suitable for bloodletting to be performed on children until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should pregnant women be bloodletted, unless from the fourth month up to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should the elderly be bloodletted, who have already passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When someone wants to be bloodletted for any reason whatsoever: it is necessary that they cleanse their intestines beforehand with a gentle clyster, if there is much retained feces in them; so that the veins do not attract noxious and putrid superfluities from the intestines during the bloodletting, which harm the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should the patient be full of toxins, that is, excessively nauseous; nor drunk, nor trembling from intoxication, until they are freed from these things.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor one who is weak with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And bloodletting should be avoided after a bout of colic passion, and vomiting, and flux of the stomach, and excessive coition, and labor, and exercise, and wakefulness, and fasting, and everything that dissolves the virtue from the bodily or animal corpus.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors beforehand, if the blood is thick from food and drinks, and medicines; if it is possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let him take a bath, if nothing prohibits it; or let him be exercised by some exercise, so that the blood is made more subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And let bloodletting be performed on him in the chest, around the third day, as we have said; and take care, so that his chest is freed from all bad animal accidents that day: such as anxiety, and anger, and fear; and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, and pain, and superfluity, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And the surgeon should make present the things with which he is familiar through the use of aromatics, and perfumes, and trips to similar places, in accordance with the quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then the phlebotomist should sit on a cushion, which should be higher than the cushion of the one being phlebotomized: afterwards he should extract his arm, and rub it with his hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he should bind the ligament with a strap, and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And the binding should be tempered, because when the binding is unequal, or excessive in the binding, then it prevents the flow of blood; or if it is too loose, then it also prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the binding, it is necessary to rub the hands of the one being phlebotomized simultaneously until the veins become swollen and declare themselves to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist should wipe away the phlebotomy with a little oil, in the ancient proper way.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he should place his index finger of the left hand on the vein below the spot where he wants to perform the phlebotomy, gently: so that the vein does not flee and the percussion is felt.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because the vein is like a fleeing string during phlebotomy: and among them there is one that is full of windiness: and when you place the phlebotomy on it, it contracts beneath the phlebotomy, and the phlebotomist is deceived, and does not open the vein: and if he opens it, it is constricted: therefore it is necessary for this reason, that the phlebotomist be steady, and be solicitous in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he should apply the phlebotomy instrument.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore the vein is opened with a single stroke, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then he should try another stroke in the same place gently, or above it with quickness: if the spot does not become inflamed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	What if he faints, or the patient becomes weak, then let him rest for a day, or two days: and do not tighten the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed he has attracted a warm abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Nor should he take a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the bloodletting, if he loves it.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	What if the opening is small, or the blood flows subtly: and so that not too much quantity exits from the blood as desired: then repeat the phlebotomy at the same opening, according to correctness, and add a little to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do that with hastening, before the place becomes inflamed, for an inflamed place is, in many men, during a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that it has already become inflamed, then do not repeat it at all, for nothing excuses it in your regard.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put upon it something from the sediment of oil: because it alleviates the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than the oil itself, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the sediment of oil in all your phlebotomies, where phlebotomists prohibit the flow of blood: and they make it a tyriacal preparation, and a sagzenic one, when it is put on the place from one of them.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For the blood is subtly thickened and resolved, when it is coarse.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	What if a great abscess occurs at the site of phlebotomy, for it often happens, especially to one who is not experienced except on that occasion, or has a small opening of the vein, then apply and put upon the place a sponge infused in water and salt, warmed for a little while: and tighten it for one hour: because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary to do that after the blood has flowed out from that vein, with a supplement of itself, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something black or greenish remains in the location after several days, it does not harm: and if you wish, apply to it some aloe solution, or myrrh, or something from the juice of mint, that is, calamen or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times indeed abscesses and swellings occur at the incision sites of bloodletting according to the method of Basil.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand therefore upon it, then if you find softness under the pressure of your hand upon it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Take heed therefore, so that you put on it something from what we have mentioned.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps a flow of blood from the artery may occur.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make an plaster for it with that in which there is sticking, so that the place may be bound together.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment, until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to extract from every man a certain quantity of blood according to the amount of his strength.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the coloring of the wine on the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it flow out, until it becomes red: and similarly if you see it thick: then let it flow out, until it becomes subtle: and similarly if it is acute, until its acuteness is relieved.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and needs the extraction of blood twice, to amplify the phlebotomy of the veins, and let the phlebotomist be skilled: and in him who is weak, let it be contrary to that.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to extract it in the veins, and that the opening be narrow: and what is better administered in phlebotomy of the veins is a transverse section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is healthy from the flow of blood, and from the incision of a nerve: and it is more praiseworthy and healthier than phlebotomy through width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to one who has become accustomed to bleeding through phlebotomy, it is necessary that they eat moderately sweet bread infused with pomegranate water: or if they are hot, let them take it out from the blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if they have a cold complexion, then let them take before phlebotomy bread infused with juice of mead, or with juice of honey aromatized with spices, or with aromatized and fragrant juice.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	What if it happens that they have a syncopic fit at the time of phlebotomy, and there is a cause for the abundant outflow of blood: then it is necessary to give them a drink of meat broth, and subtle fragrant syrup: and let them take aromatic things with galangal, and anoint their chest with it: and let them take the remaining things that we mentioned in the chapter on syncopic evacuations.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wants to evacuate their arm and release their blood a second time: it is necessary for the one whose phlebotomy is due to abundant evacuation, and their strength is weak, to release the blood gradually according to the quantity of their strength on continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wants to evacuate their arm and release their blood a second time, and their body is strong: then let them do it after seven hours, or nine hours from their first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wants to attract blood from their body to the opposite part to which it inclines: it is necessary that they be evacuated on the second day, or the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whom there is much hot and inflamed blood in their body, and it becomes sharp, and causes fever: it is necessary that the blood exit from them in one vein, and a large quantity be extracted from them: and the opening be widened until a syncopic fit occurs: after you have observed all the conditions of phlebotomy: and put your hand on their pulse at the course of the blood, so that death does not occur in place of the syncopic fit.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For it often happens that, when the phlebotomist is ignorant and careless.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not suitable when one wants to release the arm, and release the blood a second time, since the opening of the vein is already closed, and the exit of the blood becomes difficult, so that it presses excessively upon it with vehemence, and the curvature extends rapidly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a great evil, or rather, to abandon it altogether, until it is phlebotomized a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove it with the acuteness of phlebotomy that which has coagulated from the blood in the opening of the vein, and apply to it something salty dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And apply to it something from Tyriaca Alfaroch or Sagsena, and apply it with a gentle compression, until the blood flows out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the vein has become apostematous, then abandon it, and do not touch it, until the apostema settles.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	What if necessity provokes a second time to release the blood, and there is no excuse, then either phlebotomize it at that place, or in another arm at another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The veins of the arm are phlebotomized at the place of the Fusea and Basilica, when they are not found, and are hidden, since they are composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is such that it introduces a weak hand into hot water, until the skin becomes red, and the veins appear manifestly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then bind over it with a ligature of moderate constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then perform the second phlebotomy across the width gradually, not laterally, nor along the length; and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be such that you phlebotomize over the junction of the hand for a short time.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	What if the flow of blood is prohibited, then immerse the hand in hot water, and let the blood flow into the water, until you achieve your necessity.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If you are suffering from summer days, then you should avoid repeated hand washing in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed the flow of blood is greatly increased by hot water at the time of winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the bleeding of this vein is healthier for all veins, since there is no pulsating vessel under it, nor a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The bleeding of the Salvatella vein in the right hand is beneficial for liver diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this bleeding is such that you should bind the arm with a ligature or your hand, after you have inserted it into hot water, until the vein becomes inflamed and is strongly perceived by the sense.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then make an incision across the vein.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, it will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful, lest you ultimately injure your hand with the bleeding instrument.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For underneath are naked nerves of the fingers, stripped of their flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then return your hand to hot water and allow the blood to flow from it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not return it to hot water, the blood will clot at the mouth of the vein and be prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have extracted the necessary amount from the blood, then apply oil and salt to the vein: so that it may not close quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly, it is necessary to do this with every constricted branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The benefit of bleeding from the left hand is that it is helpful for spleen diseases; and do the same in this bleeding as you did in the second, equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The benefit of bleeding from the Saphena vein is for diseases that are in the lower part of the body, such as uterine diseases, and menstrual retention, and kidney weaknesses, and old ulcers of the hips and thighs, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is that he inserts his ailing foot into warm water and performs friction upon it until the veins swell; and he binds above the joint of the foot with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed the place of the veins is at the heel, appearing opposite the thumb; and they branch out from it into many branches on the surface of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, he performs phlebotomy on its larger branch, or at the heel in its collection; because it is better and more healthy.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If he performs phlebotomy on the surface of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy where you perform phlebotomy across, as if you want to cut into it; and let the phlebotomist be skilled.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the flow of blood is prohibited, then put his foot in warm water; and allow the blood to flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the phlebotomist has missed the vein at first attempt, then let him try again with phlebotomy at the upper parts, for the place is healthy and you do not fear evil from it, when you beware of the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the Saphenous vein of the other foot, equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The place of the Sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel on the outer side of the anklebone.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the benefit of his phlebotomy is to alleviate pain in the ankle, when it is due to warm blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is that he enters the bath, and fasts; and binds his leg from the side of the ankle up to above the heel with four fingers, with a long thin thread: for it does not appear except on account of that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then perform phlebotomy on it according to whatever method is possible for you, or according to the transverse technique; and it is better, either to cut into it with an incision, or to divide it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The location of it is more saliva-like, and it is hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it, and it does not appear to the senses at all: then make an incision on some branch of it, and it is the one that appears on the back of the foot, and near the ear; and be careful of the nerve, and make a flow of blood in the quantity that you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the constriction, and put a crust over the place of the incision, and bind the area tightly.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It will heal quickly.
Â¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Concerning the ventosity, and the quality of its usage.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 48.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Ventoses are made from horns, and from copper, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the ventosity is performed indeed according to two methods.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification and bloodletting; and the other is ventosity without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventosity which is without scarification, is according to two methods.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventoses that are administered with scarification and bloodletting are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the Ventosa of Alnocrati, and it is at the back of the head; and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; and the ventoses of Alhagdahim, and they are two layers of the neck from both sides together; and the ventoses of the mind, and it is under the jawbone in the lower mouth; and the ventoses of the two spatulas; and the ventosa of Alachosos on the end of the tail; and the ventoses of the two fossae, and they are in the middle of the two arms; and the ventoses of the two thighs; and the ventoses of the two hips.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed the ventosity does not draw out blood from you through the small scattered veins in the flesh, and because of that, no virtue comes out from them, just as it is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	It is not expedient to apply a treatment with fire or without fire for any ailment that arises from overindulgence, until the whole body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity prompts to apply treatment through evacuation due to overindulgence or because of habit, we administer it at every hour, at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle, and at whatever time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	Since there are men who when their blood increases, so they need to be relieved of it through evacuation, they find a heaviness in their head and dizziness.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And there are those who find fullness and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And there are those who find itchiness on their face and forehead, and darkness, and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there are those who scratch the place of their evacuation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there are those whose flatulence increases.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And there are those who find the taste of blood in their mouth: or their tongue becomes ulcerated, and they spit out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there are those whose drowsiness increases.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there are those who see in their sleep blood and redness, and wounds, and sores, and things that are similar to them.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something of those symptoms, and it is specifically during the third period of the month: we recommend that evacuation be done then, after two or three hours have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The indication for evacuation of the neck, however, is: because it contributes to heaviness in the head and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is expedient that it should be after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this indeed is instead of the phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted for one who has a cold complexion, or in whom there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of that, it is not fitting for old people to use them, and in whom there are cold headaches.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever, however, uses it constantly, will generate upon himself an obstruction.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And because of that, it is fitting to advise the practitioner, to place his hand with a gentle puff downwards, fearing the generation of an obstruction.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosatio or Alkehel is the place of dark phlebotomy, and of royal phlebotomy, and because of that it brings about asthma, and constriction of the windpipe, and fissure of the windpipe instrument, and coughing, and fullness.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is fitting to drive the Ventosa Alkehel gently, for if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosatio truly is alhagdahim, and it brings about sudden pains in the head, and blindness, and half-headaches, and perforations, and pain in the roots of the teeth; and it is the place of royal phlebotomy.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is fitting to advise the practitioner, not to press his hand with a scarification: so that he may not cut an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventosatio under the chin, however, brings about ulcers in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar things from the diseases that are in the mouth: and it is in place of phlebotomy alieherich, which are in both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventosatio of the spatula shape brings about a condition called alchafacham, which comes from inflammation and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.
